CatDescriptText: Maude Williams, domestic, Hill District and Willie Wilkes, laborer, Lawrenceville, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, May 6, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Which of these reasons do you believe is the cause of many citizens not voting: (1) Belief that 'political machine-backed' candidates are hard to defeat? (2) Lack of interest in who runs their government?" Ms. Williams' answer reads: "The reason I, myself, am not interested and am not a voter is because colored people don't get what they are supposed to, and do not get help when they need it...The men who are voted into office don't do anything after they get in...And this is especially true in the Hill District, and is the reason why I don't vote."  Mr. Wilkes' answer reads: "I think because of lack of interest...I really don't know why there's a lack of interest."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Maude Williams wearing eyeglasses and coat with fur collar, standing in front of Raab Clothes sign, Wood Street, Downtown; Portrait of Willie Wilkes wearing hat, eyeglasses, moustache, plaid shirt, and zippered jacket, holding paper bag in left arm, standing on Wood Street in front of swirled granite facade, Downtown
